Afternoon upslope/upvalley flow combined with critically low fuel moisture (2-4% in 1-hr fuels) created explosive fire conditions.

20200817_12z.description: The August 2020 California Lightning Siege was a historic dry lightning outbreak that ignited over 650 wildfires across Northern and Central California between August 16-19. Remnant moisture from Tropical Storm Fausto streaming northward collided with an intense heat dome, generating extreme atmospheric instability and massive thunderstorms with little rainfall. The resulting fire complexes (LNU, SCU, CZU, August Complex) collectively burned over 1.8 million acres and became the 1st, 4th, 6th, and 7th largest fires in California history.

This moisture interacted with a strong upper-level ridge over Nevada driving a prolonged heat wave. The collision of moisture aloft with extreme surface heat created massive atmospheric instability, generating widespread thunderstorms that produced 12,000+ dry lightning strikes with negligible precipitation.

Tropical Storm Fausto moisture advection colliding with extreme heat dome created unprecedented instability

20200906_12z.description: The Creek Fire in Sierra National Forest produced one of the largest pyrocumulonimbus (pyroCb) events ever documented in the United States on September 5-6, 2020. Driven by powerful up-canyon diurnal winds in the San Joaquin River drainage and extreme atmospheric instability during California's historic heat wave, the pyroCb reached over 50,000 feet, injecting smoke into the stratosphere.

Mid-level atmospheric instability was extreme, with steep lapse rates above the Sierra. Strong diurnal up-canyon winds in the San Joaquin River drainage pushed the fire upslope. A massive fuel loading from millions of drought-killed and beetle-infested trees provided unprecedented fuel availability.

20200907_18z.description: The 2020 Labor Day windstorm was one of the most devastating wildfire events in Pacific Northwest history. A powerful easterly windstorm driven by an anomalous upper-level ridge and southward-plunging trough produced unprecedented September east wind gusts across Oregon, igniting and explosively spreading multiple fires. Within 24-36 hours, five simultaneous megafires (>100,000 acres each) erupted across western Oregon, burning nearly as much forest west of the Cascades in two weeks (~340,000 hectares) as in the previous five decades.
20200907_18z.meteorological_setup: A high-amplitude 500mb ridge over the eastern Pacific and a mobile trough diving southward on its eastern flank created an extreme east-west pressure gradient of up to 23mb across Oregon. This drove historically strong easterly/northeasterly gap and downslope winds through Cascade passes and river valleys. Portland International Airport recorded a 52 mph easterly gust, the strongest September easterly on record. 925mb winds at Salem were unprecedented for the August-September period.

Red Flag conditions with humidity below 10% and no overnight RH recovery enabled continuous overnight fire runs. Extensive beetle-killed lodgepole pine provided highly receptive fuels.

20210629_12z.description: The absolute peak of the 2021 PNW heat dome on June 29, when Lytton, BC reached 49.6C (121.3F) -- the highest temperature ever recorded in Canada. This HRRR cycle captures the final intensification of the Omega Block before the ridge began to weaken. The subsidence inversion reached its maximum strength, with nearly cloud-free skies and extreme surface heating across the entire PNW. Lytton was destroyed by wildfire the following day. This cycle's short FHR range (0-8) targets the peak afternoon/evening hours.
20210629_12z.meteorological_setup: The Omega Block reached peak amplitude on June 29, with 500mb geopotential heights at all-time record values over southern BC. Maximum subsidence aloft compressed and warmed the lower troposphere, with the strongest sinking motion centered over the interior valleys of BC where Lytton is located. Antecedent soil moisture depletion from 3 days of extreme heat further amplified sensible heat fluxes. The thermal low at the surface intensified, but the upper-level ridge was too strong for any sea-breeze or onshore flow penetration until late evening.

20211230_06z.description: The Marshall Fire on December 30, 2021 became the most destructive wildfire in Colorado history, evolving into a suburban firestorm in southeastern Boulder County during an extreme downslope windstorm. A mountain wave produced sustained winds of 50-60 mph with gusts of 100-115 mph that maintained intensity for nearly 11 hours. The fire destroyed 1,084 structures in Louisville, Superior, and unincorporated Boulder County, causing over $2 billion in insured losses. It was uniquely devastating as a winter grassland fire in an urban-wildland interface.
20211230_06z.meteorological_setup: An intense mountain wave developed as very strong westerly jet-level winds raced over the Front Range and crashed down onto the adjacent plains. The southward migration of the large-scale jet axis across Boulder County triggered a transition into enhanced upper-level descent, amplifying the downstream mountain wave. The highest gust of 115 mph was recorded by an APRS station. Multiple locations along the foothills recorded 100+ mph. The complete absence of snowfall that season (unprecedented drought since July) left fine fuels critically dry despite it being late December.

Already-saturated soils from earlier rains led to catastrophic landslides and river flooding from the French Broad to the Swannanoa to the Nolichucky river basins.
